question: Consider the following compound logical proposition: (P → Q) ∧ (¬Q). Determine whether this proposition is satisfiable (can be true for some assignment of truth values to P and Q) or unsatisfiable (always false regardless of the truth values of P and Q). Carefully analyze the proposition using logical equivalences and truth values.
answer:
To determine if the proposition (P → Q) ∧ (¬Q) is satisfiable, I'll analyze it step by step:

1) First, let's recall that P → Q is logically equivalent to ¬P ∨ Q

2) So our proposition becomes: (¬P ∨ Q) ∧ (¬Q)

3) Using the distributive property: (¬P ∧ ¬Q) ∨ (Q ∧ ¬Q)

4) Since Q ∧ ¬Q is a contradiction (always false), this simplifies to: (¬P ∧ ¬Q) ∨ False = ¬P ∧ ¬Q

5) This means our original proposition (P → Q) ∧ (¬Q) is logically equivalent to ¬P ∧ ¬Q

6) The expression ¬P ∧ ¬Q is true when P is false and Q is false

7) Therefore, the proposition is satisfiable, specifically when P = false and Q = false.

Alternatively, we could have created a truth table:
When Q is false, ¬Q is true
When Q is false, P → Q is true only when P is also false
So when P = false and Q = false, (P → Q) ∧ (¬Q) evaluates to true ∧ true = true

The proposition is satisfiable with the assignment P = false, Q = false.
